section.title: Deployment
section.para: Peergreen Server incorporates an advanced deployment system tailored to take advantages of (nowadays common) multi-core architectures, providing a massively parallel archive processing. This system is highly modular and can be extended to support any type of archives (beyond natively supported types). Deployment system also supports persistence of archive deployment.

section.title: Natively supported artifacts
section.para: As Peergreen Server is built from scratch on top of OSGi, bundles are first class citizen in the deployment system.
The platform also natively support 2 other artifact types: OW2 JOnAS deployment plans (more to read here) and OW2 JOnAS Configuration Admin XML files.

section.title: Persistence
section.para: Persistence support means that an archive marked as persistent will be re-installed automatically at each server restart. On the contrary, unpersisted archives will never be re-installed at server restarts.

section.title: Dropins deployment
section.para: When launching the server, a deploy/ directory is automatically created (if not already present). This directory is observed/scanned periodically and all detected changes (new files and deletions) are handed over the deployment system for processing (respectively for deployment and undeployment). Archives placed in this directory are non-persistent.

warning.para: Dropins archives are not persistent and are properly undeployed between server restarts.

section.title: Command line interface
section.para: Peergreen Server comes bundled with shell commands for deployment system management.

Theses commands can be used to:
Deploy new artifacts (persistently or not)
guillaume@peergreen-platform$ deployment:deploy-artifact file:///Users/guillaume/.../bundle.jar 03/04/13 14:36:27 (I) BasicDeploymentService.__M_process : Artifacts '[Artifact[name=file:///Users/guillaume/.../bundle.jar, uri=file:///Users/guillaume/.../bundle.jar, mode=DEPLOY]]' in '92' ms. Report: file:///Users/guillaume/.../bundle.jar: OK Process done in '92' ms.
Use the -p (--persistent-mode) command flag to activate persistent deployment (false by default)
List currently deployed artifacts
guillaume@peergreen-platform$ deployment:list file:///Users/guillaume/.../bundle.jar
Undeploy previously installed artifacts
guillaume@peergreen-platform$ deployment:undeploy-artifact file:///Users/guillaume/.../bundle.jar 03/04/13 14:55:04 (I) BasicDeploymentService.__M_process : Artifacts '[Artifact[name=file:///Users/guillaume/.../bundle.jar, uri=file:///Users/guillaume/.../bundle.jar, mode=UNDEPLOY]]' in '12' ms. Report: file:///Users/guillaume/.../bundle.jar: OK Process done in '12' ms.
Display a detailed report for a given deployed artifact
guillaume@peergreen-platform$ deployment:report-artifact file:///Users/guillaume/.../bundle.jar Artifact[name=file:///Users/guillaume/.../bundle.jar, uri=file:///Users/guillaume/.../bundle.jar, totalTime='6' ms] |-Facet[name=com.peergreen.deployment.facet.archive.Archive, addedBy=com.peergreen.deployment.internal.processor.uriresolver.FileURIProcessor] |-Facet[name=org.osgi.framework.Bundle, addedBy=com.peergreen.deployment.internal.facet.osgibundle.processor.OSGiBundleInstallProcessor] |-Facet[name=com.peergreen.deployment.facet.archive.OSGiBundle, addedBy=com.peergreen.deployment.internal.facet.osgibundle.processor.OSGiBundleArchiveProcessor] |-Processor[name=com.peergreen.deployment.internal.facet.osgibundle.processor.OSGiBundleArchiveProcessor, phase=FACET_SCANNER, duration='0' ms] |-Processor[name=com.peergreen.deployment.internal.facet.osgibundle.processor.OSGiBundleStartProcessor, phase=START, duration='1' ms] |-Processor[name=com.peergreen.deployment.internal.facet.osgibundle.processor.OSGiBundleInstallProcessor, phase=INSTALL, duration='2' ms] |-Processor[name=com.peergreen.deployment.internal.processor.uriresolver.FileURIProcessor, phase=URI_RESOLVER, duration='1' ms]

section.title: Monitored artifacts
section.para: When deployed, artifacts become managed artifacts, a monitoring Thread tries to detect (periodically) if the artifact has changed, if so, it notifies the deployment system of the change, propagating an UPDATE order.

section.title: Remote management
section.para: Peergreen Server provides a simple Telnet daemon that can be used to connect to a running instance.
By default, it opens the 10023 port and listen for connections on all network interfaces.
Peergreen server supports up to 2 concurrent telnet connections.

glossdef.para: Comma separated list of ports to use for listening (if empty default 10023 port will be used)

section.title: Connecting
section.para: When a connection attempt is made to one of the bound address, the daemon simply creates a new shell console and connects connection's input and output stream into the console. Any telnet client can be used to connect to this daemon. Type exit for exiting the session (without shutdowning the platform).

section.title: Telnetd commands
section.para:
Peergreen's Telnetd comes bundled with 2 commands to inspect the daemon and its connections status: telnetd:info and telnetd:connections.
info is useful to see telnetd configuration (open ports, ...) and statistic informations on connections (current, failed, ...).
connections gives informations about each currently open connection (origin, opening date)

note.para: Detailed command information are available in the command reference guide.
